labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

comments.author: dimmyvi
comments.body: closing the PR
The receiver device can bind to the mailbox before getting the secret. I'm not sure if it is worth making that distinction here, but wanted to call it out.

The sender's device is bound to the Relay server during mailbox creation. I think it would be worth adjusting the language here to make it clear that the sender's device was bound to the relay server earlier.

Receiver device claims the mailbox at the time it makes a call to read secure content. 
Reading OpenGraph display info doesn't require a claim token
Thanks Alex; I think it's stated above (binding a Sender device). Here just wanted to emphasize that a pair of devices are bound to the mailbox.

I would propose to split this section into several sub-sections, e.g.
x.1) Sender/Receiver safety
- Relay server shall be trusted by both Sender and Receiver devices
- Receiver must be notified by Relay server in case integrity of provided URL was altered (*NEW1)
x.2) Sender/Receiver privacy
- At no time Relay server shall store or track the identities of both Sender and Receiver devices.
x.3) Credential's security(Confidentiality and integrity)
- Content of the mailbox shall be only visible to devices having Secret.
- It is recommended to send URL to the mailbox and the Secret over different channels (out-of-band) from Sender device to Receiver device (e.g. send URL over SMS and Secret over iMessage).
- Relay server MUST not receive the Secret with the MailboxIdentifier at any time.
- Content of the mailbox must be protected in integrity with cryptographic checksum (*NEW2)

So this way we can categorise different aspects that contributes into overall  security of such solution 

*NEW1: I wanted to introduce integrity over URL
Idea would be to mandate Sender to compute some(subject to discuss) form of checksum over URL and deposit on Relay server along with credential's content. Thus, when Receiver presents the URL to Relay server, the Relay server can now re-compute and verify checksum stored vs computed. Having this mechanism in place we can reduce the surface of attacks where someone will try to mess up the mailbox identifier along with a secret and try to redirect Receiver into a different mailbox created by malicious actor that might contain some sort of exploit/shell code, etc. 

*NEW2: Another idea that I wanted to bring forward is integrity protection over content stored in the mailbox.
We can use a Secret as a Master Key(MK) and derive ENC and MAC Keys from that MK. Therefore, ENC will be used to protect content's confidentiality and MAC Key to generate(by Sender) cryptographic checksum that can be validated by Receiver upon content download.

Key derivation scheme can benefit from randomness of mailbox identifier, so subject to discuss.
Re-phrased the sentence.

Added bullet-points to the section. 
(*NEW1) When you say  " checksum over URL "  - do you mean
a checksum over URL string - like sha256("relay.apple.com/v1/m/1234-abcd")?
Store this in the mailbox, so each time Relay can compute the checksum over the URL actually called and match these 2?
If so, how does it work with DNS names and VIPs/ load balancers? 
The actual application running on a mailbox may not know the actual dns name exposed to devices...
We can provide it to the app via configuration params, but that would not necessary be the actual dns name being called...

(*NEW2)Or a checksum over the mailbox content (like MAC code)?
We currently use Authenticated encryption (AES-GCM) which provides both confidentiality(encryption) and integrity(mac) of the content. We have discussed the idea of key derivation based on the mailbox Identifier, but it seems not provide any actual security benefits. If the attacker can guess the mailbox Id, they still be able to both read the mailbox content and use the same identifier in key derivation...
Thus we still have 2 key attributes that guaranty security of the mailbox - a random unique mailbox Identifier and a secret based on strong cryptographic RNG.

pulls.title: Update draft-secure-credential-transfer.md regarding specific endpoints' 401
pulls.author: nicksha
pulls.body:
* Removed response `401` from ReadDisplayInformationFromMailbox. This endpoint does not need to check for device claim and should be accessible publicly. 
* Updated `401` description for `ReadSecureContentFromMailbox`.

pulls.title: Modified workflow graphs for consistency
pulls.author: nicksha
pulls.body:
* Updated workflow graphs to use endpoint api terms consistently
* Updated workflow graphs to use consistent language and label placement
* Updated workflow graphs to include flow lines for `encrypted info`

pulls.title: Minor formatting of the workflow graphs
pulls.author: nicksha
pulls.body:
* All calls to the relay server from device are labeled on top of call arrow and centered.
* All response from relay server are labeled below of response arrow and centered.
* New lines between call/response blocks.

comments.author: dimmyvi
comments.body: Added RelinquishMailbox endpoint - to unbind invalid Receiver device

While the Relay server doesn't limit the number of round trips we've said that reusing the same symmetric key isn't sufficient from a security POV. I don't know if we need to include that here, but wanted to call out that if we were to use this for a chatty provisioning we might need to use the first few messages to upgrade the channel's encryption.
If this is optional then it doesn't think it provides any security benefit. A bad actor could just not send one up. @matthewcbyington what do you think?

pulls.title: Add Expiration Field To ReadSecureContentFromMailbox
pulls.author: alexpell00
pulls.body:
This PR adds a new expiration field to the `ReadSecureContentFromMailbox` json response. This value can be leveraged by receiving clients to show when the share will expire.

If a sender wanted to show the share expiration in the open graph preview then they could include the date in the description string when creating the mailbox.

comments.author: matthewcbyington
comments.body: @nicksha @crystalyq Everyone OK with this change? I am planning to merge it today if so.

comments.author: matthewcbyington
comments.body: @alexpell00 pending Google's approval we will merge this in. I concur with the change.

comments.author: matthewcbyington
comments.body: Merging this in given lack of concerns for a few days. Thanks @alexpell00 !
